definition: to be on the lookout/to keep watch
full moon/to hope/to expect/to visit/to gaze (into the distance)/to look towards/towards
15th day of month (lunar calendar)/old variant of 望[wang4]
wind/news/style/custom/manner/CL:陣|阵[zhen4],絲|丝[si1]
to flee at the mere sight of (idiom)
see 捕風捉影|捕风捉影[bu3 feng1 zhuo1 ying3]

sentences.english: The lookout ran out and escaped in the getaway car.
sentences.chinese: 望风的人跑出去跳上那辆车就逃走了。

sentences.english: That little boy likes to keep nix for his brothers .
sentences.chinese: 那个小男孩喜欢为他的哥哥们望风。

sentences.english: Mendizábal told Rosenberg that the man was clearly acting as a lookout.
sentences.chinese: 蒙迪扎巴尔告诉罗森博格，这家伙显然是在望风。

sentences.english: A bad credence, the likelihood makes you all client flee at the mere sight of the oncoming force .
sentences.chinese: 一个不好的信用，可能让你所有客户望风而逃。

sentences.english: Well, it really is but a shadowy supposition .
sentences.chinese: 呃，其实这不过是一种望风捉影的悬想。

sentences.english: He hid the lantern in Huck's sugar hogshead and the watch began.
sentences.chinese: 他把灯笼藏在哈克的糖桶里，开始望风。

sentences.english: The team members seem to take turns acting as look-out.
sentences.chinese: 快餐团队的成员似乎轮流望风。

sentences.english: A child on the watch, came towards them to beg;
sentences.chinese: 一个望风的男孩走过来向她们讨钱。

sentences.english: Xiao Wang stood on guard and we felt our way into the lane.
sentences.chinese: 小王望风我们摸着黑走进那条小巷。

sentences.english: Two boys waited outside as lookouts.
sentences.chinese: 有两个男孩站在门外望风。

definition: to keep watch/to do sentry duty/to be on patrol
to wait for an opportunity/to watch for one's chance
colleague/co-conspirator/accomplice
to follow sb/to tail/to shadow
to guard/to watch over
to monitor secretly/to spy on
henchman/gang member
to form a gang
to keep watch (during a clandestine activity)/to be on the lookout
insect that damages cereal crop seedlings/(lit. and fig.) vermin/a person harmful to the country and the people
to dispose of stolen goods
to tail behind/to tag along/to follow on the heels of
to seize an opportunity/to exploit (a loophole)
to coordinate outside and inside offensives (idiom)/(fig.) to act together
to flee in disorder/to scurry off
to escape without trace (idiom); to make one's getaway (from the scene of a crime)/to show a clean pair of heels
